Function to convert output of regulondb queries to GenomicRanges objects

Source: R/get_dataset.R
convert_to_granges.Rd

This function converts, when possible, a regulon_result object into a GRanges object.

convert_to_granges(regulondb_result)

Arguments

regulondb_result

A regulon_result object.

Value

A GRanges object.

Examples

## Connect to the RegulonDB database if necessary
if (!exists("regulondb_conn")) regulondb_conn <- connect_database()
#> snapshotDate(): 2020-03-31

## Build the regulon db object
e_coli_regulondb <-
    regulondb(
        database_conn = regulondb_conn,
        organism = "E.coli",
        database_version = "1",
        genome_version = "1"
    )

## Obtain all the information from the "GENE" dataset
convert_to_granges(get_dataset(e_coli_regulondb, dataset = "GENE"))
#> Warning: Dropped 19 entries where genomic coordinates were NAs

#>      [1] #>      [2]                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               ModB is the predicted integral membrane subunit of an ABC transporter that mediates the high affinity uptake of molybdate. <i>modB</i> encodes a hydrophobic protein with 5 predicted transmembrane regions |CITS: [8564363] [7665460]|.
#>      [3]                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         CysZ is a high affinity, high specificity sulfate transporter which mediates sulfate uptake for the purpose of cysteine synthesis |CITS: [24657232]|.<br>CysZ interacts with sulfate, sulfite, sulfide and cysteine but does not interact with thiosulfate. CysZ mediates sulfate uptake into whole cells and proteoliposomes. CysZ mediated sulfate uptake is inhibited by sulfite. CysZ is a sulfate:proton symporter but the exact stoichiometry of the transport reaction is not known |CITS: [24657232]|.<br>A <i>cysZ</i> mutant is deficient in sulfate assimilation |CITS: [6302202]|.
#>      [4]                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           The <i>dfp</i> (<i>coaBC</i>) gene encodes a bifunctional protein that catalyzes two sequential reactions<br>in the coenzyme A biosynthetic pathway |CITS: [11278255][11358972][10922366]|.  The C-terminal<br>(CoaB) domain of the protein confers phosphopantothenoylcysteine synthetase activity; CoaB alone forms<br>dimers in solution |CITS: [12140293]|, and crystal structures of this domain have been solved<br>|CITS: [15530362]|.  The N-terminal (CoaC) domain of the protein binds FMN and confers<br>4'-phosphopantothenoylcysteine decarboxylase activity |CITS: [10922366][11358972]|.  The domain can be<br>expressed separately and forms dodecamers |CITS: [11358972]|.<br>The existence of a 4'-phosphopantothenoyl-CMP intermediate in the synthetase reaction has been<br>confirmed |CITS: [14686929]|.<br>A pathway for formation of the substrate-activating thioaldehyde for the decarboxylation reaction has been<br>proposed |CITS: [11427085]|, and the stereochemistry of the reaction has been studied |CITS: [12565925]|.<br><i>dfp</i> is an essential gene |CITS: [12142426]|.  A temperature-sensitive allele has been isolated<br>|CITS: [2999089]|.<br>
#>      [5] DcuB is a C4-dicarboxylate transporter; DcuB functions primarily as a fumarate:succinate antiporter during anaerobic fumarate respiration.<br><i>dcuB</i> and <i>dcuA</i> encode predicted inner membrane proteins with high sequence similarity; <i>E. coli dcuB</i>::Kan or <i>dcuA</i>::Spc single mutants do not have impaired growth under anaerobic fumarate, malate or aspartate respiration; the double mutants (<i>dcuB</i>::Kan <i>dcuA</i>::Spc) have severely impaired growth under these same conditions |CITS: [7961398]|. DcuB catalyses the export of succinate coupled to the uptake of fumarate, malate or aspartate |CITS: [7961398]|. <br>When grown under anaerobic conditions <i>E. coli</i> K-12 displays transport activities for uptake, efflux and exchange of C4-dicarboxylates. Fumarate:succinate exchange is required for fumarate respiration while succinate efflux (without exchange) occurs during glucose fermentation; net uptake of C4-dicarboxylates is observed experimentally when no counter substrate is present. The exchange reaction is electroneutral while uptake and efflux are electrogenic symport reactions probably of the dicarboxylate with 3 H<sup>+</sup> (|CITS: [1512189][8020497]| and see review by |CITS: [11803016]|). <i>E. coli</i> K-12 contains 3 C4-dicarboxylate transporters (DcuA, DcuB and DcuC) that are active under anaerobic conditions; a strain lacking all three (<i>dcuA</i>::Spc <i>dcuB</i>::Kan <i>dcuC</i>::mini-Tn10) is not able to grow anaerobically on fumarate plus glycerol; all three are active in both exchange and uptake; DcuB favours an exchange reaction over uptake |CITS: [8955408]|.<br>DcuB is predicted to have 10 transmembrane helices with the N- and C-terminal residues in the periplasm |CITS: [9733683]|.  <br>Expression of <i>dcuB</i> is induced anaerobically by FNR and by C-4 dicarboxylates |CITS: [9852003]|. <i>dcuB</i> is repressed by CRP-cAMP and by nitrate acting through the NarXL regulatory system |CITS: [9852003]|. Expression of <i>dcuB</i> is induced by C4-carboxylates through the |FRAME: PWY0-1468 DcuSR two-component system| |CITS: [9765574][9973351][29203472]|. Deletion of <i>dcuB</i> results in constitutive expression of a <i>dcuB'-'lacZ</i> reporter gene fusion in the absence of fumarate. This activation is dependent on the presence of DcuS and suggests that DcuB has a regulatory function in addition to a transport function. Specific point mutations have been identified which differentiate between these two functions |CITS: [18957436]|.  <br>Activation of <i>dcuB</i> by free DcuS (DcuS<sub>F</sub>) and a DcuB-DcuS complex at low concentrations or under conditions in the absence of C<sub>4</sub>-dicarboxylate results in standby expression of <i>dcuB</i>. Free DcuS<sub>F</sub> regulates <i>dcuB</i> expression, up to 8% of the maximal DcuB levels formed |CITS:[29203472]|. On the other hand, the DcuB-DcuS complex drives most <i>dcuB</i> expression in the presence of fumarate at 100 &mu;M |CITS:[29203472]|.<br>Reviews: |CITS: [27134023][27415771]|<br>

#>   [4582]                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        YlcJ was identified as a previously unannotated small protein that is expressed during exponential phase in rich growth medium |CITS: [29645342]|.<br>
#>   [4583]                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       The small regulatory RNA SdhX connects the expression of TCA cycle genes to acetate metabolism.  SdhX represses expression of AckA |CITS: [30541135][30591570]|, FdoG and KatG in <i>E. coli</i> |CITS: [30541135]|.  <br>SdhX was originally detected as a 103 nt Hfq-interacting small RNA |CITS: [14622403]|.  SdhX is processed from the <i>sdhCDAB-sucABCD</i> mRNA by |FRAME: EG10859-MONOMER RNase E|; |FRAME: EG10438-MONOMER Hfq| appears to play a role in processing |CITS: [30591570]|.<br>SdhX expression is regulated at the transcriptional level identically to the <i>sdh</i> operon promoter, |FRAME: PM00143|, and is not affected by posttranscriptional regulation exerted by the small RNA regulators RybB, RyhB and Spot 42 |CITS: [30591570]|.  <br>Overexpression of SdhX increases resistance to hydroxyurea via its effect on <i>ackA</i> expression, and deletion of <i>sdhX</i> reduces the growth lag during exposure to hydrogen peroxide, likely due to its effect on <i>katG</i> expression |CITS: [30591570]|.
